div1.p: IN THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT OF THE NINTH CIRCUIT IN AND FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE PETITION OF ERNEST HUTCHINSON for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.

The petitioner in this cause insists that Sec. 7 of Ordinance No. 6036 is unconstitutional and void, because of the license imposed upon the business of selling goods by the use of trading stamps. The same question was before the Supreme Court of the State of Washington in the case of T.J. Fleetwood v. J.H. Read, 21 Wash., page 547. This was a case involving the validity of an ordinance of the City of Tacoma, which requires mechants using trading stamps for the sale of goods to pay an annual license of one hundred dollars, Sections one and two of said Ordinance, which are found on pages 550 and 551 - 21 Wash., are as follows:

"Section 1. Every person, firm or corporation within the City of Tacoma who shall use and stamps, coupons, tickets, cards or other devices for the sale of goods, wares, and merchandise, which said stamps, coupons, tickets or other similar devices shall entitle the purchaser receiving the same to procure from any other firm or corporation, any goods, wares or merchandise free of charge upon production of any nu,ber of said stamps, tickets, coupons, cards or other similar devices, shall, be using the same, obtain a license, therefor from the city clerk.

"Sec. 2. Before obtaining such license the person applying therefor shall pay to the city treasurer the sum of one hundred dollars; and upon such payment being made and filing a receipt therefor with the city clerk, the city clerk shall issue to the firm or corporation making such payment a license to use, for one year, the stamps, coupons, tickets, cards or other similar devices mentioned in Section 1 of this ordinance."
Subdivisions one and two of Sec. 7 of Ordinance No. 6036, of the City of Seattle, are as follows:

"Sec. 7. Subdivision 1. It shall be for any one to sell, offer or attempt to sell goods and merchandise by selling trading stamps, checks, tickets or other thing of whatever name to merchants, the same by such merchants being delivered to customers upon the purchase of goods and merchandise, and then exchanged by such customers with the person selling such trading stamps, checks, tickets or other thing of whatever name for his goods and merchandise, without first paying into the city treasury the sum of six hundred dollars, and upon receipt showing such payment, procuring a license, issued by the city comptroller, authorizing the same. Such license shall be issued for the period of twelve months.

"Subdivision 2.Any merchant who deals in or uses any trading stamps, checks or tickets mentioned in subdivision one of this section must also firs pay into the City Treasury the sum of one hundred dollars, and upon receipt showing such payment, procure a license, issued by the City Comptroller, authorizing the same. Such license shall be issued for the period of twelve months.

It will be noticed that there is no difference between the two ordinances, excepting that the Seattle ordinance requires the payment of a license of six hundred dollars a year by the person who sells the trading stamps to the merchants. The exact principle involved in each case, and as it is not contended that the amount of license is unreasonable, the position of respondent must be upheld or the case cited overruled.
We contend that the position of respondent is correct and that Sec. 7 of Ordinance No. 6036 should be upheld.

Our State Supreme Court also upheld an ordinance of New Whatcom requiring a license of twenty-five dollars per day for selling stocks of merchandise: W.C. Stull v. J.P. DeMattos, et al., 23 Wash., page 71; and also a license fee of one hundred dollars per year upon the bsuiness of pawnbroking was upheld in the case of the City of Seattle v. R.W. Barto, 31 Wash., page 141. In this last case, the title
of the same ordinance, 6036, was involved, as well as the license imposed and the contention of the City upheld.
Repsectfully submitted, Mitchell William, Ellis De Bruler and H.A. Wilson. Attorney for Respondent.
In the United States Circuit Court FOR THE DISTRICT OF Washington Northern Division
In the petition of Ernest Hutchinson for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Mitchell WIlliam Ellis DeBruler H.A. Wilson Attorney for Respondent
